episodes.natural_language:
This narrative covers the Dana Jackson case (Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024), involving client Dana Jackson in a motor vehicle accident claim, with communications focused on PIP (Personal Injury Protection) benefits and the associated police report.

In February 2024, communications began with an email dated February 9, 2024. Aries Paul Peñaflor of Whaley Law Firm sent a message to Ashley Joyner with the subject 01007187244, stating that an attached file should be reviewed. The email included a confidentiality notice and listed multiple insurance entities: Permanent General Assurance Corporation; Permanent General Assurance Corporation of Ohio; The General Automobile Insurance Company, Inc.; Old American County Mutual Fire Insurance Company (TX only); and Homesite Insurance Company of Georgia (GA only). The message was signed with “All the best, Aries Paul Peñaflor, Whaley Law Firm” and provided the firm’s contact details.

On February 13, 2024, Dana Cohen, a desk adjuster with MedPIP Operations at The General Insurance (an AmFam Group Company), replied to Aries. At 4:01 PM, Cohen wrote: Good Afternoon, in order for us to move forward with PIP we need the police report. Do you have a copy? Thank you. Thereafter, Aries confirmed that the police report was attached. Cohen’s message and Aries’s confirmation of the attached police report appear in the same email thread, which also included the standard sign-off for Dana Cohen and the General Insurance contact information. The February 13 exchange is part of the ongoing process to obtain the police report necessary to advance PIP processing.

By early March 2024, the correspondence shifted to the status of PIP payouts. On March 7, 2024 at 11:05 AM, Dana-Morae Cohen, Desk Adjuster MedPIP Operations, sent a reply noting updated PIP logs for the clients. She stated that $6,665.00 had been paid out for Cecil and $5,735 had been paid out for Dana, and she asked for guidance on how to proceed with their PIP benefits. This message was part of the internal update to the case’s PIP status.

That same day, March 7, 2024, a forward of Cohen’s update was sent to the Filevine project email addresses associated with Cecil Finley and Dana Jackson. The forward carried the subject line “Re: 01007187244” and displayed the original message from Cohen detailing the PIP payout amounts described above. The forwarded message was dated at 13:31:33 -0500 and was addressed to Cecil Finley’s Filevine project email and Dana Jackson’s Filevine project email, ensuring both parties were informed of the updated PIP status.

In summary, the case’s key chronological elements include the February 9, 2024 initial attachment from Whaley Law Firm concerning claim 01007187244; the February 13, 2024 exchange in which the police report was requested and then confirmed as attached; and the March 7, 2024 update from Dana Cohen detailing PIP payouts ($6,665.00 for Cecil, $5,735 for Dana) and seeking direction on next steps, followed by the March 7 forwarding of that update to the relevant Filevine recipients.
episodes.author: Aries

Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. Client: Dana Jackson. This note documents a sequence of email communications regarding the motor vehicle accident case for Dana Jackson, specifically referencing file number 01007187244 and involving Whaley Law Firm and The General Insurance (an AmFam Group company).

On July 8, 2024, Aries Penaflor of Whaley Law Firm sent an email with the subject 01007187244 to Kristen Akande, addressed to Dana Jackson’s filevine inbox. The message began with the line Some people who received this message don't often get email from aries@whaleylawfirm.com. Learn why this is important, followed by: Hi Dana, Please see attached file. The email was signed by Aries Paul Peñaflor of Whaley Law Firm, and included his Ph: 502-365-5788 and Fax: 502-364-9363. The body also carried a confidentiality notice and boilerplate from Whaley Law Firm, along with a disclosure listing affiliated insurers: Permanent General Assurance Corporation; Permanent General Assurance Corporation of Ohio; The General Automobile Insurance Company, Inc.; Old American County Mutual Fire Insurance Company (TX only); Homesite Insurance Company of Georgia (GA only). The message indicated that Dana should review the attached file and was concluded with a customary closing, All the best, Aries Peñaflor, Whaley Law Firm.

The next day, July 9, 2024, a response was sent in the chain from Dana-Morae Cohen, listed as Desk Adjuster MedPIP Operations for The General Insurance, an AmFam Group Company. In a message dated around 10:00 AM, labeled RE: 01007187244, Cohen wrote to Aries Penaflor: Good Morning, Per your request, please see the attached. Thank you. The signature block identified her as Dana Cohen, Desk Adjuster MedPIP Operations, with an address of 6000 American Parkway, Madison, WI 53783. Her office phone was 800.280.1466 ext 6347 and her fax was 615.695.4471, and the company was The General Insurance, an AmFam Group Company. The message also included an image placeholder described as A black and white sign, Description automatically generated with medium confidence.

In the forwarded/chain context, the July 8 Whaley Law Firm email to Kristen Akande is shown as a preceding message in the thread, with the subject 01007187244 and the note that some recipients do not often receive emails from aries@whaleylawfirm.com. The content of that prior message was the directive Hi Dana, Please see attached file, followed by the sign-off All the best, Aries Paul Peñaflor, Whaley Law Firm, with the Whaley contact information (Ph: 502-365-5788; Fax: 502-364-9363) and the standard confidentiality notice. The email also carried the Whaley Firm’s boilerplate about confidentiality and a listing of the associated insurance entities as noted above.

In sum, the file reference 01007187244 was the focal point of the July 8 and July 9, 2024 email exchanges between Whaley Law Firm (Aries Penaflor) and Dana Jackson’s insurers (Dana Cohen of The General Insurance), with an attached file and an image accompanying Cohen’s reply. The case remains a Dana Jackson motor vehicle accident matter dated January 24, 2024.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Call - Discussed Litigation Phase of Claim - Advised that Complaint was filed, Def was Served, DC Filed Answer & we are currently awaiting the DC to Serve Disc Req on Him - They have served Disc Req on Companion Finley already - Discussed Litigation & typical 24 months from filing to Trial (even everything runs smoothly) - Advised there are multiple times along the way that we may be able to settle the claim - Advised we have to at least get through Discovery before settlement can be discussed currently - Advised Client to reach out with any questions, however, until DC serves him w/Disc Req there will not be much movement - He expressed understanding & appreciated the update - Client did advised Email Address on file is no longer good - He will set up new email today or tomorrow & text in new email - Sent Client Filevine Text for New Email Address 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: November 12 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on November 12, 2024, with Sarena regarding Dana Jackson’s motor vehicle accident case (Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024). I discussed the litigation phase of the claim, explaining that the complaint has been filed, the defendant has been served, and the DC filed an answer; we are currently awaiting the DC to serve Disc Req on him. They have already served Disc Req on Companion Finley. We discussed the typical 24-month timeline from filing to trial, noting that even if everything runs smoothly, the process can take about two years. There are multiple points along the way where we may be able to settle the claim, but settlement discussions cannot be held until discovery is complete.

I advised the client to reach out with any questions; however, until DC serves him with Disc Req there will not be much movement. He expressed understanding and appreciated the update. The client advised that the email address on file is no longer good; he will set up a new email today or tomorrow and text in the new address. A Filevine text was sent to the client for the new email address.

Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024
Client: Dana Jackson

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Call from Client - Checking Status - Advised Awaiting DC Disc Req PP to him - As a passenger, DC may not request - Companion has been served DC Disc Req - Client asked about PIP coverage - Advised PIP was approved - Reviewed Payments made & discussed distribution of any remaining PIP Benefits - Advised not eligible to be paid directly to him at this time - Roughly $6100 paid to Starlight - Appears ER may be outstanding - Will be submitted to PIP if confirmed outstanding - Client expressed understanding - Client asked about Legal Lending - $1500.00 - Advised highly recommend against but understand the necessity - Will send to AW for review - Client appreciated the assistance 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: December 17 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on December 17, 2024 with Dana Jackson regarding the motor vehicle accident case Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. The client called to check the status of the matter.

During the call, I advised that we are awaiting a DC Disc Req PP to him; as a passenger, DC may not request it, and the companion has been served the DC Disc Req. The client asked about PIP coverage, and I advised that PIP was approved. I reviewed payments made and discussed the distribution of any remaining PIP benefits, noting that the client is not eligible to be paid directly to him at this time. Approximately $6,100 has been paid to Starlight, and it appears an ER balance may be outstanding; the claim will be submitted to PIP if an outstanding balance is confirmed. The client expressed understanding. The client asked about Legal Lending in the amount of $1,500; I advised that I highly recommend against it but understand the necessity, and I will send this to AW for review. The client appreciated the assistance. The person making contact was Sarena.

In the case file Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024, involving client Dana Jackson, the Whaley Law Firm correspondence was sent on Friday, January 10, 2025 at 10:42:51 AM Eastern Time. The email, titled “Re: Dana Jackson Certified Medical Billing Error,” was from Sarena Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to Starlite Chiropractic with copies to Starlite Chiropractic at lgsweasy@gmail.com and to Bryce Koon at bryce@whaleylawfirm.com. The message notes that on December 19 a request was made for clarification on the certified medical billing related to Dana Jackson, and, to date, there has been no response.

The primary concern raised is a discrepancy between the pre-litigation billing and the certified billing. Specifically, the Pre-Lit Billing shows $6,770.00, while the certified billing shows only $1,725.00. The email states that this discrepancy needs to be addressed because the case is in the discovery phase of litigation and Mr. Jackson’s responses are approaching overdue status. If clarification is not provided soon, the firm asserts they will be limited to claiming only $1,725.00 for Starlite’s facility, which would hurt Mr. Jackson’s settlement and also means Starlite will not receive full consideration for payment. The email requests immediate contact to discuss the matter in further detail.

The message also references a prior email from December 19, 2024, sent by Sarena Tuttle at approximately 1:55 PM, which stated: “Thank you so much for the corrected Certification Page. Unfortunately, when I went to note the Bills, I noticed the Certified Billing only shows $1,725.00 in Charges while the Uncertified Billing shows $6,770.00. In addition the $1,725.00 bill shows $1,100.00 in payments but no adjustment to the balance, please clarify.” This earlier communication is included with the same sign-off and contact details.

The email is signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Direct line: (502) 357-9971; Office: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; Email: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is a new email address. The correspondence is part of the ongoing effort to reconcile the certified and uncertified billing figures in Dana Jackson’s case during the discovery phase of litigation.

Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. Client: Dana Jackson.

Dana was the subject of a discovery request communications thread from The Whaley Law Firm regarding her motor vehicle accident claim. The case file includes a forwarded message that was originally sent on December 20, 2024, with the subject “The Defense Counsel's Discovery Request - Due back by January 10, 2025.” The message was addressed to Dana at jacksondana950@gmail.com and was CC’d to Bryce Koon. In that message, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note: please use the new email address), asked Dana to review the attached discovery request packet from the Defense Counsel and to answer the questions to the best of her recollection. The packet contained twenty items, which included the following: 1) Any and all employers at the time of the incident and/or after; 2) Skip—Irrelevant; 3) List any persons other than Cecil and the Defendant who may have witnessed the incident; 4) Describe how the accident took place in Dana’s own words; 5) Skip—Premature Disclosure; 6) Skip—Premature Disclosure; 7) Skip—Bryce will compile & answer; 8) Describe Dana’s injuries in her own words; 9) List any prior significant injuries/illnesses (e.g., broken bones, pulled muscles, surgeries, etc.); 10) List any subsequent significant injuries/illnesses; 11) Have you had any prior accidents, yes or no, and if yes, please list; 12) Skip—Duplicative to 11; 13) Ensure we have a list of medical providers including your Primary Care Physician related to your accident; 14) List any medical providers for any prior injuries or surgeries; 15) Skip—Duplicative to 4; 16) Were you wearing your seatbelt? Yes or No; 17) Skip—Irrelevant, you were not the driver; 18) Do you have any photographs related to the incident or your injuries?; 19) Do you have private health insurance? If so, please send us a copy of your card; 20) Have you ever been convicted of a felony? Yes or No, and if Yes, please provide the year, charge, and case outcome.

The sender instructed Dana to answer these questions to the best of her recollection, with the stated due back date of January 10, 2025.

Subsequently, on January 13, 2025, at 3:03 PM Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle again sent Dana a similar notice from the same Defense Counsel packet. This second message was addressed to BXFinest83@gmail.com, again requesting Dana review the attached discovery request packet and provide answers to the same twenty questions by the same recall standard, with the same twenty items and the same “Skip” designations and notes (e.g., Bryce will compile & answer, duplicative items, etc.). The January 13 message again included Sarena Tuttle’s signature and contact information, including the note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

In both messages, the content of the twenty-item list remained consistent. The items included requests to identify current and past employers, identify witnesses beyond Cecil and the Defendant, recount the accident in Dana’s own words, describe injuries and prior or subsequent injuries, list prior accidents, compile medical provider information (including the primary care physician related to the accident and providers for prior injuries), confirm whether Dana wore a seatbelt, confirm if she has any photographs of the incident or injuries, determine private health insurance status (and provide a card if applicable), and disclose felony convictions with year, charge, and case outcome if applicable. The messages repeatedly noted that Bryce would compile and answer item 7 and labeled several items as duplicative or irrelevant (e.g., items 2, 5, 6, 12, 15, 17).

AI Summary:
Reviewing activity in Dana Jackson MVA 1/24/2024 between 12/25/2024 and 1/24/2025...

This case involves a motor vehicle accident where Dana Jackson and Cecil Finley are plaintiffs against defendant Justin Kiebler. The incident occurred on January 24, 2024, resulting in injuries to Dana Jackson, including neck, back, hip, and arm pain.
The most recent activity shows that the plaintiffs' attorney, Bryce Koon, sent a follow-up email on January 22, 2025, to the defense counsel requesting an update on the defendant's discovery responses, which are overdue. (See details)
A potential red flag is the discrepancy in medical billing from Starlite Chiropractic. The pre-litigation billing shows $6,770.00, while only $1,725.00 was certified, which could impact the settlement and payment to the medical provider. (See details)
The next recommended step is to follow up with Starlite Chiropractic to clarify the billing discrepancy and ensure accurate representation of medical expenses in the discovery responses. Additionally, continue to press for the defendant's overdue discovery responses. (See details), (See details)
episodes.natural_language:
Dana Jackson and Cecil Finley are the plaintiffs in a motor vehicle collision case against defendant Justin Kiebler. The incident occurred on January 24, 2024, and Dana Jackson sustained injuries including neck, back, hip, and arm pain.

During a review of activity in the Dana Jackson MVA matter for the period from December 25, 2024, to January 24, 2025, the most recent item shows that the plaintiffs’ attorney, Bryce Koon, sent a follow-up email on January 22, 2025 to defense counsel requesting an update on the defendant’s discovery responses, which are overdue.

A potential red flag is a discrepancy in medical billing from Starlite Chiropractic. The pre-litigation billing shows $6,770.00, while only $1,725.00 was certified, which could impact the settlement and payment to the medical provider.

The next recommended steps are to follow up with Starlite Chiropractic to clarify the billing discrepancy and ensure accurate representation of medical expenses in the discovery responses, and to continue pressing for the defendant’s overdue discovery responses.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. Client: Dana Jackson.

The Defense Counsel’s Discovery Request for Dana Jackson’s motor vehicle accident claim carried a due date of January 10, 2025. The matter includes an email chain in which the discovery request was first sent to Dana on December 20, 2024. In that forward, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm addressed Dana at jacksondana950@gmail.com with the subject The Defense Counsel’s Discovery Request - Due back by January 10, 2025 and asked Dana to review the attached discovery request packet and answer the following questions to the best of her recollection. Bryce Koon was cc’d on the email. The attached packet contained twenty questions, with instructions indicating that some items were to be skipped as Irrelevant or Duplicative, and others were designated for Bryce to compile. The questions covered topics such as employment at the time of the incident, witnesses other than Cecil and the Defendant, a narrative description of how the accident occurred, injuries, prior and subsequent injuries, prior accidents, medical providers related to the accident, seatbelt use, photographs, private health insurance, and felony convictions. Specific responses and placeholders in the December 20, 2024 initial request mirrored the enumerated twenty questions present in the correspondence. The message concluded with the standard signature block for Sarena M. Tuttle, including her title (Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager), firm (The Whaley Law Firm), address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), and contact information (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note indicating the email address is current).

The defense follow-up and Dana’s responses were carried forward in January 2025. On January 13, 2025, Dana replied, stating that she had answered the questions below and that the answers were included in bold, and she invited any further requests. Later that same day, Sarena Tuttle circulated the responses to the Discovery Request as follows:

1) Any & All Employers at the time of the incident and/or after: None.
2) Skip - Irrelevant.
3) List any persons other than Cecil and the Defendant that may have witnessed the incident: None.
4) Describe how the accident took place in your own words: “we were driving the other driver backed out the driveway into the highway and hit us.”
5) Skip - Premature Disclosure.
6) Skip - Premature Disclosure.
7) Skip - Bryce will compile & answer.
8) Describe your injuries in your own words: “hurt my neck, lower and upper back, right hip and arm.”
9) List any prior significant injuries/illnesses (ex. broken bones, pulled muscles, surgeries, etc): None.
10) List any subsequent significant injuries/illnesses: badly bruised.
11) Have you had any prior accidents, yes or no, if yes, please list: No.
12) Skip - Duplicative to 11.
13) Make sure we have a list of your medical providers including your Primary Care Physician related to your accident: (no specific list provided in the response).
14) List any medical providers for any prior injuries, surgeries: (no specific list provided in the response).
15) Skip - Duplicative to 4.
16) Were you wearing your seatbelt? Yes or No: (no answer provided in the record).
17) Skip - Irrelevant, you were not the driver: (statement included in the packet).
18) Do you have any photographs related to the incident or your injuries: No.
19) Do you have private health insurance? If so, please send us a copy of your card: No.
20) Have you ever been convicted of a Felony? Yes or No, If Yes, please provide the Year, Charge, Case Outcome: (no answer provided in the record).

The signature block for Sarena M. Tuttle followed, listing her position, firm, and contact information, including the address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: 502-357-9971), office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and email (E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), with a note confirming the email address as current.

For context, the chain shows the initial forward on December 20, 2024, introducing the same discovery request packet and questions, sent to Dana Jackson at jacksondana950@gmail.com and cc’d to Bryce Koon, with Sarena reiterating the request and the same twenty questions. The subject line in that forward was The Defense Counsel’s Discovery Request - Due back by January 10, 2025. The forwarding email was followed by Dana’s January 13, 2025 response, and Gerold Reynolds later acknowledged with a note that he had answered the questions below and that the items were in bold, requesting to know if anything else was needed. The attorney contact details and firm information are reiterated in both the forward and the subsequent messages.

On January 22, 2025, at about 3:32 PM (time shown as 3:32?PM in the record), Bryce Koon followed up again. He wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, Just wanted to follow up on this one again – please advise when we may expect your client’s responses in this regard.” He again provided his contact information and the firm’s disclaimer, and he reiterated the need for a response.

Please advise when we may expect responses. If I do not hear back from you in this regard, I will be forced to file a motion to compel.” This message again included the Whaley Law Firm signature block and the standard privilege/disclaimer language.

The communications were directed to counsel for the opposing party and included copies to Dana Jackson and others involved in the matter, and every message concluded with the firm’s confidentiality and privilege disclaimer.

Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024
Client: Dana Jackson

In the matter of Finley & Jackson v. Justin Kiebler (Jefferson 24-CI-005774), relating to client Dana Jackson, the following email communications occurred between counsel starting in December 2024 and continuing through February 2025. The initial outreach was on December 27, 2024, when W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Deborah Campbell Myers, Esq., of Dilbeck & Myers PLLC, with copies to Cecil Finley (the Filevine project email address), Dana Jackson (the Filevine project email address), Sarena Tuttle, and the Dilbeck & Myers attorneys. In that message, Koon stated that he had reviewed the discovery with his opposing counsel and that while the responses to the requests for admission had been filed, the remaining discovery responses had not yet been provided. He requested an update and warned that if no update was received, he would pursue a motion to compel.

On January 22, 2025, there were additional follow-up messages. In the first Jan. 22 note, Bryce Koon again asked for guidance on when the opposing party’s client responses could be expected. The communication included the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer typical of these exchanges, noting that the message was intended only for the named recipient and that disclosure or distribution should not occur if the message was received in error.

Later on January 22, 2025, another message from Koon reiterated the request for the other party’s client responses and again carried the standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

By February 17, 2025, the exchange continued with another follow-up from Koon. He stated that he wished to know when he could expect the outstanding discovery responses and again warned that, if no response was received, he would be forced to file a motion to compel. This message also carried the same confidentiality language as prior emails.

On February 17, 2025, Deborah Myers, replying at 1:22 p.m. in the same thread, apologized for the delayed reply. She explained that she had reviewed the discovery with Mr. Kiebler and was working on the responses, but she was currently in a short trial that week and would be out of the office the following week, which would slow her ability to provide the responses for final review and signature. She requested the courtesy of an additional three weeks. In her message, Myers reiterated her contact details and reminded the recipients of the confidentiality and privilege protections. The thread included multiple CCs and the same set of recipients as prior messages, and the exchanges continued to include the standard attorney-client privilege notices.

Across these communications, the parties remained focused on producing the outstanding discovery responses for the Finley & Jackson v. Kiebler case, with Dana Jackson as the client and the matter proceeding in Jefferson County under the case number 24-CI-005774.

episodes.natural_language:
This note summarizes the discovery-related communications in Finley & Jackson v. Justin Kiebler (Jefferson County, case number 24-CI-005774) involving Dana Jackson, in connection with the motor vehicle accident case file titled Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. The principal counsel across the exchange were W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Deborah Campbell Myers, Esq., of Dilbeck & Myers PLLC. The subject line of the correspondence was Re: Finley & Jackson v. Justin Kiebler (Jefferson 24-CI-005774). The email chain includes the following participants and recipients: Bryce Koon, Deborah Myers, Cecil Finley (Filevine project email), Dana Jackson (Filevine project email), Sarena Tuttle (Whaley Law Firm), and an “Attorneys” distribution list at Dilbeck & Myers. The messages contain standard confidentiality notices typical of attorney communications distributed to multiple recipients, stating that the emails are intended only for the named recipients and that if received in error, the sender should be notified and the information should not be disclosed.

On December 27, 2024, Bryce Koon wrote to Deborah Myers regarding outstanding discovery responses. He noted that while responses to the requests for admission had been filed, the parties had not yet provided responses to the remaining discovery requests, and he requested an update on those remaining responses. This email included the Whaley Law Firm contact information (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) and the Dilbeck & Myers contact information (8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-595-6500; fax 502-595-6504) in the signature blocks, along with the confidentiality notice.

Several weeks later, on January 22, 2025, Bryce Koon followed up again on the outstanding discovery requests. In a message at approximately 3:32 PM, he asked for an update on when the opposing party would provide their client’s responses and warned that he would be forced to file a motion to compel if no response was forthcoming. A subsequent follow-up that same day, at around 1:07 PM, reiterated the request: to advise when the client’s responses could be expected, with the same warning about potentially filing a motion to compel if there was no timely response. These messages were also accompanied by the standard confidentiality notices and the signature blocks for The Whaley Law Firm.

On February 17, 2025, Deborah Myers replied to Bryce Koon. She apologized for what appeared to be a lapse in responding to his earlier email and explained that she had reviewed the discovery with opposing counsel, Mr. Kiebler, and that she was still working on the discovery responses. She noted that she was in a short trial that week and would be out of the office the following week, which would slow her ability to send the responses for final review and signature. She requested a courtesy extension of three weeks to complete the responses. She thanked Bryce for his professional courtesy in this regard. Her message included her firm’s contact details (Dilbeck & Myers PLLC, 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-595-6500; fax 502-595-6504; deborah@dilbeckandmyers.com) and carried the standard confidentiality notice.

In response, Bryce Koon acknowledged his understanding of the situation and thanked Deborah for the update, adding that he would check back in a couple of weeks.

These notes reflect that the matter centers on discovery in the Jefferson County case Finley & Jackson v. Justin Kiebler (24-CI-005774), involving Dana Jackson as a client, and concern the timing and scope of responses to discovery requests, including admissions and the broader set of discovery requests. The communications reveal the parties’ intent to avoid motion practice by coordinating timelines, with the February 17, 2025 exchange establishing a three-week extension request due to trial commitments and scheduling constraints on counsel.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024
Client: Dana Jackson

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Client called repeatedly back to back (4x within 30-45 minutes) yesterday - Reviewed - Sent Update to Client via Text:

Good afternoon Dana,
We noticed you call multiple times (back to back) yesterday. Unfortunately, our office was closed due to impending winter storm that was expected. Please keep in mind multiple phone calls will only delay our response time as we wade through all the client voicemails who call multiple times.
However, Bryce has spoken with the Defense Counsel and the Defense has requested a 3 week extension to respond to our Discovery Request sent to the Defendant Driver. This extension grants a new deadline of March 11, 2025. If the Defense has not responded on March 12, 2025, Bryce will file a Motion to Compel with the courts. This motion will be set for the 1st available Monday.
Once the Defendant Responses are received, there is a 30 day review period. If no other documents are needed, we will move forward with Deposition Scheduling. If additional documents/information is required, Deposition scheduling will be delayed until all written discovery is complete. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 20 2025

The client had called repeatedly yesterday, making four back-to-back calls within a 30- to 45-minute window. A review was completed and an update was sent to Dana via text.

The text update, authored by Sarena of The Whaley Law Firm, reads: "Good afternoon Dana, We noticed you call multiple times (back to back) yesterday. Unfortunately, our office was closed due to impending winter storm that was expected. Please keep in mind multiple phone calls will only delay our response time as we wade through all the client voicemails who call multiple times. However, Bryce has spoken with the Defense Counsel and the Defense has requested a 3 week extension to respond to our Discovery Request sent to the Defendant Driver. This extension grants a new deadline of March 11, 2025. If the Defense has not responded on March 12, 2025, Bryce will file a Motion to Compel with the courts. This motion will be set for the 1st available Monday. Once the Defendant Responses are received, there is a 30 day review period. If no other documents are needed, we will move forward with Deposition Scheduling. If additional documents/information is required, Deposition scheduling will be delayed until all written discovery is complete. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail." The message closes with "-Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm." The contact was made by Sarena, and the date and time noted for this contact is February 20, 2025.

Additionally, the note states that Bryce has spoken with the Defense Counsel, and the Defense has requested a 3 week extension to respond to the Discovery Request addressed to the Defendant Driver. This extension sets a new deadline of March 11, 2025, and if the Defense has not responded by March 12, 2025, Bryce will file a Motion to Compel with the courts, with the motion to be set for the first available Monday. After the Defendant's responses are received, there is a 30-day review period. If no further documents are needed, we will proceed with Deposition Scheduling; if additional documents or information are required, deposition scheduling will be delayed until all written discovery is complete. For any questions, Dana is encouraged to contact the firm directly to discuss them further.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Call - Looking for Update - Did not receive Text from last week

Discussed DC Request for 3 week extension - Discussed new deadline 03.12 - Discussed what a MTC is & how that works - Client asked about approx Resolution Time - Advised Client Extension takes us to 03.11, if Resp Recvd & Written Disc Complete, we will schedule depos around/in April - with Post Depo Review looking at May 2025 before discussing settlement - Possible will have to schedule mediation if DC not willing to discuss settlement - Client expressed understanding and appreciated the update - Client will mark calendar to give us a call around 03.13

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 24, 2025, with Dana Jackson regarding a motor vehicle accident case (Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024). The client had called seeking an update and had not received a text from the previous week.

During the call, we discussed the DC request for a three-week extension and the new deadline of March 12. We discussed what a MTC is and how that works. The client asked about an approximate resolution time. We advised that the extension takes us to March 11; if the response is received and the written discovery is complete, we will schedule depositions around or in April, with a post-depo review looking at May 2025 before discussing settlement. It is possible we will have to schedule mediation if DC is not willing to discuss settlement. The client expressed understanding and appreciated the update. The client will mark their calendar to give us a call around March 13. The contact was made by Sarena. Date & Time: February 24, 2025.

Dana Jackson is a client in a motor vehicle accident case titled Finley & Jackson v. Justin Kiebler (Jefferson 24-CI-005774). This note is a forwarded chain relating to scheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions, with the May 22, 2025 date ultimately proposed to proceed via Zoom. The forward was sent on April 23, 2025, by W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, to Cecil Finley’s Filevine email and Dana Jackson’s Filevine email, along with counsel for the defendant. The message, dated 11:19:55 a.m. Eastern Time, stated that May 22, 2025 beginning at 10:00 a.m. would work. The email also included a standard privilege/confidentiality notice indicating the message is for the named recipients only and that a privilege may apply; if received in error, recipients should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose or share the information.

The chain begins with a separate message from April 23, 2025, at about 7:53 a.m., in which the recipient list consisted of counsel and the firm’s administrative assistant, Rena Martin at Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC. In that message, Rena asked for confirmation that May 22, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m. via Zoom is acceptable for the depositions of the Plaintiffs, and she indicated she looked forward to hearing from the recipients.

Earlier, on April 16, 2025, at 9:56 a.m., Rena Martin of Dilbeck & Myers sent a reply to the Whaley firm (cc’ing Deborah Campbell Myers and Bryce Koon) proposing that the depositions of the Plaintiffs be held on May 22, 2025, with Cecil Finley first at 10:00 a.m. and Dana Jackson immediately thereafter, both via Zoom. She asked the recipients to confirm that this schedule was acceptable so that Notices could be prepared.

Prior to that, on April 15, 2025 at 4:22 p.m., Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, advised Rena that their office and clients could be available on any date between May 19 and May 30. Sarena noted that Mr. Jackson is an out-of-state resident and would need his deposition to occur via Zoom. She expressed an expectation to calendar these depositions and included her contact details.

There was a further exchange on April 15, 2025, at 12:51 p.m., when an email from the Dilbeck & Myers firm stated: “This will follow up on Ms. Myers’ request for deposition dates in this matter. I look forward to hearing from you.” The message was signed by Rena Martin, Administrative Assistant, with the Dilbeck & Myers contact information.

On April 1, 2025, Deborah Campbell Myers of Dilbeck & Myers—addressed to Bryce Koon and with Sarena Tuttle and the Whaley firm cc’d—requested to move forward with scheduling plaintiffs’ depositions now that written discovery was complete. Deborah asked whether Mr. Kiebler should also be deposed and noted that her office had been added to assist with scheduling. She asked for several dates convenient for all parties and clients and emphasized her willingness to coordinate. Her signature included her title, firm, address (8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222), phone and fax numbers, and a warning about the confidential nature of the transmission.

In summary, the series of emails documents the parties’ efforts to schedule the depositions of the plaintiffs, Cecil Finley and Dana Jackson, in the case Finley & Jackson v. Justin Kiebler. The agreed or proposed plan, as repeatedly discussed in the chain, was to hold the depositions on May 22, 2025, beginning with Finley at 10:00 a.m. and Jackson immediately afterward, all via Zoom, with Dana Jackson’s deposition noted as requiring remote participation due to his out-of-state status. The communications indicate that the notices would be prepared following confirmation, and they reflect coordination among The Whaley Law Firm, Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, and the involved clients.

episodes.natural_language:
This case concerns Finley, et al. v. Kiebler, with Dana Jackson listed as the client. The file is titled Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. In a thread dated June 13, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, reached out to opposing counsel regarding scheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions. The email was sent to the attorneys at Dilbeck & Myers and to Deborah Myers, with Cecil Finley and Dana Jackson copied to their Filevine project email addresses. The message was dated Friday, June 13, 2025, at 1:57:53 PM (GMT-04:00). In the message, Koon apologized for the delay and asked whether the recipients were available on Tuesday, July 1 or Wednesday, July 2.

Earlier in the thread, an email was sent on June 13, 2025 at approximately 9:58 AM from Dilbeck & Myers. The Administrative Assistant, Rena Martin, wrote to follow up on Deborah Myers’ request for dates to reschedule the plaintiffs’ depositions and stated, “I look forward to hearing from you.” The message included Dilbeck & Myers’ contact details: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222, and phone number (502) 595-6500. This followed Deborah Myers’ prior message in the chain.

Deborah Campbell Myers of Dilbeck & Myers PLLC had previously emailed Bryce Koon on Friday, May 30, 2025 at 10:27 AM. In that correspondence, she requested proposed dates for the rescheduling of the plaintiffs’ depositions from May 22, 2025, and she advised that State Farm had sent a lien notice from Conduent regarding Mr. Finley, attaching the related notice. Deborah signed with the firm’s details: Dilbeck & Myers PLLC, 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; Telephone: 502-595-6500; Fax: 502-595-6504; deborah@dilbeckandmyers.com. The email also contained the standard confidentiality notice, stating that the transmission contains private and confidential information, and instructing the recipient who received it in error to notify the sender and not to disclose, copy, distribute, or rely on the information.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024. Client: Dana Jackson. This file relates to the matter captioned Finley, et al. v. Kiebler. The communications below concern scheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions and were exchanged among counsel on June 13, 2025, with prior outreach beginning May 30, 2025.

On May 30, 2025 at 10:27 a.m., Deborah Campbell Myers of Dilbeck & Myers PLLC sent an email to Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm requesting proposed dates to reschedule the plaintiffs’ depositions that had originally been set for May 22, 2025. Deborah also noted that State Farm had sent her the attached lien notice from Conduent regarding Mr. Finley. She asked to hear back and closed with well wishes for the weekend. Deborah’s message included her contact details and a standard confidentiality notice stating that the email and transmitted documents contain private and confidential information, and that if received in error the recipient should notify the sender, avoid disclosure, and not use or forward the information.

Later on June 13, 2025, at 9:58 a.m., Rena Martin, Administrative Assistant at Dilbeck & Myers, followed up on Deborah Myers’ request for dates to reschedule the plaintiffs’ depositions, inviting a response.

In the early afternoon of June 13, 2025, at 1:58 p.m., Bryce Koon replied to the chain, informing Deborah that he had spoken with his clients and asking whether they would be available on Tuesday, July 1, or Wednesday, July 2.

Later that same day, at approximately 2:30 p.m., Deborah replied that she was not available on the proposed dates, but she was free all day on July 3 and asked if that would work. She also indicated that she would need to check with Mr. Kiebler.

At 2:49:15 p.m. (GMT-04:00) on June 13, 2025, Bryce responded that he was not available on July 3 and proposed alternative dates of July 9 or July 10. His message remained within the same thread and carried the standard attorney-contact information for The Whaley Law Firm, including his Louisville address, phone, and fax numbers, and the same recipient and CC list as the prior messages.

The thread includes multiple CCs: Attorneys at Dilbeck & Myers, Cecil Finley’s Filevine project email, and Dana Jackson’s Filevine project email. The subject line across the thread reads “Re: Finley, et al vs. Kiebler.” Each message in the thread includes the customary attorney-client privilege and confidentiality disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and should not be shared if received in error; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information.

In sum, the communications establish ongoing efforts to reschedule the plaintiffs’ depositions in Finley, et al. v. Kiebler, with Deborah Myers proposing July 3 as an available date after the initial dates were found unavailable, Bryce Koon proposing July 1 or 2 or later dates (July 9 or 10), and no agreement reached as of the latest messages. The May 30 email also referenced a lien notice from Conduent related to Mr. Finley, and the thread maintained its standard confidentiality notices throughout.

episodes.natural_language:
This note summarizes a June 2025 email thread about rescheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions in the Finley, et al. v. Kiebler matter, with Dana Jackson listed as the client in the Dana-Jackson-MVA-1-24-2024 file. The subject line for the exchanges is Re: Finley, et al vs. Kiebler. The initial message in this thread is an email from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, dated June 13, 2025, 3:11:34 PM Eastern Time, sent to Deborah Myers at Dilbeck & Myers, with copies to the Dilbeck & Myers attorney list and to the Filevine project email addresses for Cecil Finley and Dana Jackson. The body of that first message simply read, “Sounds good thank you.” Bryce’s signature follows, listing The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information. The transmission also includes the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer that accompanies this firm’s electronic communications.

The thread continues with Deborah Myers’s reply, sent the same day at 3:11 PM. Deborah states that she is available on 7/9/25, will place a hold on that date, and will reach out to Mr. Kiebler. She signs as Deborah Campbell Myers of Dilbeck & Myers, with the firm’s address in Louisville and a notice reiterating the confidential nature of the communication.

Earlier on June 13, 2025, Bryce had asked for availability on July 1 or July 2, indicating he was unable to meet on the 3rd. Specifically, at 1:58 PM he wrote to Deborah (and cc’d the same recipients as before) asking, “Are you all available Tuesday, July 1 or Wednesday, July 2?” He added his WaSalut signature details after the message.

Deborah responded at 2:30 PM the same day, informing Bryce that she is not available on those dates, that she is free all day on 7/3 if that works, and that she would need to check with Mr. Kiebler before confirming anything.

 Bryce replied again at 2:49 PM, noting that he is not available on the 3rd and proposing alternative dates: 7/9 or 7/10.

Deborah followed up at 3:11 PM with confirmation that she is available on 7/9/25, that she would place a hold on that date, and that she would contact Mr. Kiebler. This message appears to be part of the same scheduling dialogue, continuing the effort to coordinate a deposition date.

Separately, in this email chain, there is an earlier communication from May 30, 2025, in which Deborah wrote to Bryce requesting proposed dates for rescheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions from May 22, 2025. Deborah also noted that State Farm had sent her an attached lien notice from Conduent concerning Mr. Finley. Deborah’s May 30 message included her contact details for Dilbeck & Myers, as well as a confidentiality notice. The thread shows follow-up from Rena Martin, Administrative Assistant at Dilbeck & Myers, dated June 13, 2025 at 9:58 AM, indicating that this would follow up on Deborah Myers’s request for deposition rescheduling and that she looked forward to hearing back.

In sum, the parties are arranging to reschedule the plaintiffs’ depositions, with initial proposals for dates including July 1, July 2, and July 3 being rejected or uncertain, and a final tentative agreement emerging for July 9, 2025, with Deborah indicating availability and a plan to confirm that date with Mr. Kiebler. The communications involve Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm; Deborah Myers of Dilbeck & Myers; and participants associated with Dana Jackson and Cecil Finley via Filevine project email addresses. The case matter remains Finley, et al. v. Kiebler, and the deposition rescheduling discussion is tied to the broader Dana-Jackson-MVA file.

episodes.natural_language:
Case context: The notes pertain to the Finley, et al. v. Kiebler matter, with Dana Jackson identified as a client (related to a separate Dana Jackson MVA matter). The communication thread on June 13, 2025, was between The Whaley Law Firm (W. Bryce Koon, Esq.) and the Dilbeck & Myers firm (Deborah Myers, with Rena Martin as administrative contact) regarding rescheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions and related matters.

The thread begins with an email from Bryce Koon dated June 13, 2025 at 3:28:52 PM, sent to Deborah Myers and copied to other attorneys and Filevine project addresses. In that email, Bryce responds with an uncomplicated, “That is fine with me for now,” and signs his name and contact information. The message also includes The Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice.

Earlier in the thread, Deborah Myers had asked Bryce to forward proposed dates for rescheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions, which had originally been scheduled for May 22, 2025. She also noted that State Farm had sent a lien notice from Conduent pertaining to Mr. Finley.

On June 13, 2025 at 3:12 PM, Bryce replied that he had checked with his clients and asked whether they were available on Tuesday, July 1, or Wednesday, July 2. Deborah responded at 2:30 PM the same day, stating that she was not available on those dates and was free all day on July 3, adding that she would also need to check with Mr. Kiebler.

Bryce replied at 2:49 PM, clarifying that he was not available on July 3 and proposing alternatives of July 9 or July 10. He signed off with his usual contact information. Deborah then sent a follow-up note at 3:11 PM indicating that she was available on July 9, 2025, and that she would place a hold on that date and reach out to Mr. Kiebler. Bryce responded shortly thereafter with a brief acknowledgment, saying “Sounds good, thank you.”

In a later message from Deborah, she wrote, “Bryce, I just looked back and only the plaintiffs were originally scheduled; do you want to just do that again?” which indicates a consideration of rescheduling the deposition of the plaintiffs consistent with prior arrangements. The thread ends with these discussions about dates, keeping the focus on rescheduling the plaintiffs’ depositions in light of the lien matter and the coordination between the two firms.

Throughout the thread, the parties reference proposed dates and availability, with the key tentative arrangement centering on July 9, 2025 as a potential deposition date, and with ongoing coordination about confirming attendance with Mr. Kiebler. The communications are anchored by the May 30, 2025 inquiry from Deborah about proposing new dates and noting the Conduent lien, and are followed by multiple back-and-forths on available dates in early July, leading to the tentative plan for July 9, 2025.
